main.name: Dr. Saurabh Bhaskar Shaw
main.description: Experienced data scientist, translational neuroscientist, and neurotechnology enthusiast
main.bio: I am a translational neuroscientist focused on using machine learning tools to better understand the spatiotemporal dynamics of brain networks and to develop clinically viable neurotechnologies aimed at improving the clinical diagnosis and treatment of neurological and psychological disorders, such as PTSD and concussion. To accelerate the conception and development of such novel translational neurotechnologies, I co-founded NeurotechHA, the Hamilton chapter of the global NeurotechX organization, with the objective of unifying interdisciplinary researchers, industry partners and clinicians with a common interest in applying neurotechnologies to improve health outcomes.
main.bio_current: I am currently a MITACS post-doctoral fellow at the Homewood Research Institute (HRI), and the Department of Psychiatry at Western University, under the supervision of Dr. Ruth Lanius, where I am applying my machine learning (ML) and artifical intelligence (AI) expertise to translate research-findings into clinical neuromarkers of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), aiming to improve diagnosis and treatment of such psychological disorders. I also am a postgraduate affiliate of the Vector Institute for Artificial Intelligence (AI), Toronto.
main.bio_past: I completed my PhD under the supervision of Dr. Sue Becker at McMaster University, where my work focused on identifying signatures of brain networks using a cheaper and more clinically feasible imaging modality (EEG), compared to the current norm (fMRI), for better diagnosis of patients with complex mental health disorders (e.g. PTSD). I also completed my Bachelor's and Master's degree in Electrical and Biomedical Engineering from McMaster University, while developing better treatment tracking tools for concussion, and applying machine learning to improveme medical imaging of muscle. Read more about my research training and projects below...

education.description: Under the supervision of Dr. Sue Becker, my work focused on improving our understanding of brain network dynamics and creating a clinically feasible tool capable of tracking the activity and synchrony of such brain networks, to be used as biomarkers for better treatment planning and tracking treatment response in patients with PTSD. I was awarded the NSERC Alexander Graham Bell Canada Graduate Scholarship (CGS-G), a prestigious national scholarship, for this doctoral work.

I worked on creating a proof-of-concept Brain Computer Interface (BCI) capable of identifying mild Traumatic Brain Injury (mTBI) under the co-supervision of Dr. John Connolly and Dr. Michael Noseworthy, and was awarded the national NSERC Canada Graduate Scholarship - Masters (CGS-M) for this work. I also collaborated with Dr. Dinesh Kumbhare on bringing machine learning based improvements in detecting muscle knots using ultrasound in the trapezius muscle.

As a three-time NSERC Undergraduate Research Award (USRA) scholar, I engaged in numerous research projects aimed at 1. improving the artifact-filtering of real-time EEG data, in collaboration with InteraXon; and 2. developing multinuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) capability to detect 31P and 13C compounds in the brain.
